skill.name: citation-management
skill.description: Comprehensive citation management for academic research. Search Google Scholar and PubMed for papers, extract accurate metadata, validate citations, and generate properly formatted BibTeX entries. This skill should be used when you need to find papers, verify citation information, convert DOIs to BibTeX, or ensure reference accuracy in scientific writing.
skill.summary: Comprehensive citation management for academic research. Search Google Scholar and PubMed for papers...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: The skill includes six Python scripts that access scholarly databases (CrossRef, PubMed, arXiv, Google Scholar) and read/write user-provided BibTeX files. All network calls target legitimate academic APIs documented in the code. The scripts' behavior matches the stated purpose of citation management. No obfuscation, hidden execution paths, or credential theft patterns were detected. Two minor concerns involve HTTP usage for arXiv API and optional proxy configuration for scholarly library rate limiting.

low_findings.title: arXiv API uses plain HTTP
low_findings.description: The arXiv API endpoint uses HTTP: `url = 'http://export.arxiv.org/api/query'`. An attacker with network access could observe or modify metadata responses. The queried data is public scholarly metadata with no sensitive user data.

low_findings.title: Optional free proxy for scholarly
low_findings.description: Google Scholar search can optionally route traffic through free proxies: `pg.FreeProxies()` and `scholarly.use_proxy(pg)`. Proxy operators could observe search queries. This is explicitly optional, disabled by default, and documented in the script.

content.value_statement: Citation data is inconsistent across sources and drafts. This skill searches scholarly databases, extracts metadata, and validates BibTeX for accurate references.
actual_capabilities: Search PubMed with E-utilities and export JSON or BibTeX
Search Google Scholar using the scholarly library
Convert DOIs to BibTeX via doi.org content negotiation
Extract metadata from DOI, PMID, arXiv ID, or URL
Format, sort, and deduplicate BibTeX files
Validate BibTeX fields and optionally verify DOIs
limitations: Requires network access to CrossRef, PubMed, arXiv, and doi.org
Google Scholar search depends on the scholarly Python library
DOI verification can be slow and depends on external services
Outputs are limited to BibTeX or JSON formats

use_cases.title: Build a thesis bibliography
use_cases.description: Find papers, convert DOIs, and validate the BibTeX list before submission.

use_cases.title: Validate PubMed citations
use_cases.description: Run MeSH searches and verify required fields and DOI formats.

use_cases.title: Clean shared BibTeX files
use_cases.description: Format, deduplicate, and sort team bibliographies for consistency.

prompt_templates.title: Search a topic
prompt_templates.prompt: Search PubMed for reviews on CRISPR gene editing from 2021 to 2024 and export to BibTeX.

prompt_templates.title: Convert DOIs
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert these DOIs to BibTeX and save to refs.bib: 10.1038/s41586-021-03819-2 and 10.1126/science.1258096.

prompt_templates.title: Batch metadata
prompt_templates.prompt: Extract metadata for identifiers in identifiers.txt and output a clean BibTeX file named references.bib.

prompt_templates.title: Validate and prioritize
prompt_templates.prompt: Validate references.bib with DOI checks and list the top five errors to fix first.

output_examples.input: Validate my BibTeX file and tell me what to fix first.
output: Found 3 errors: missing journal, invalid year, and invalid author separators.
Recommended fixes include adding DOI and page ranges for two entries.

best_practices: Use precise search queries with date ranges
Run formatting and validation after each batch
anti_patterns: Running Google Scholar search without installing scholarly
Ignoring missing required fields in validation output

faq.question: Is it compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. The prompts and scripts work with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code.

faq.question: What are the main limits?
faq.answer: Results depend on external APIs and the scholarly library for Google Scholar.

faq.question: Can it integrate with LaTeX or Zotero?
faq.answer: It outputs BibTeX that works in LaTeX and imports into reference managers.

faq.question: Does it access personal files or credentials?
faq.answer: It reads only files you provide and uses optional NCBI environment settings.

faq.question: What should I do if a search fails?
faq.answer: Check network access, API status, and query syntax, then retry with fewer results.

faq.question: How does it compare to manual entry?
faq.answer: It reduces errors by pulling authoritative metadata and validating required fields.
